Updated: September 30, 2024 @ 5:50 am Grier Hopkins Grier Hopkins is running for the Fairbanks North Star Borough mayor’s seat. Hopkins was born and raised in Fairbanks. He was an Alaska House Representative for District 4 from 2018 to 2022, with a strong focus on education and labor. He has worked as a private-sector labor representative, negotiator and organizer for the employees of the Fairbanks North Star Borough School District. Education funding has been a constant discussion for the past few years. How do you think the borough should address it at the local level? As new families look where to live, our schools are the first thing many will look at to see if we are a good place to move. The first thing we need to do is to go to the state capitol and have the legislature permanently increase funding for schools. This will keep taxes down and improve local schools of all kinds — correspondence, charter and neighborhood schools. Here locally, to sustainably bring new funding to our school district, we must build our economy with new construction and good jobs. This will build our revenue base keeping tax cap intact, and help fund our schools. I’m a product of our local public schools, and I want them to be as great for my daughter as they were for me and my wife. Our schools will be my priority, because they are the foundation of any growing and thriving community. Outside of education, what are the most pressing concerns the borough should focus on? I care deeply about the success of our entire community, and I am running to put it on the path to a bright future, but we can’t do that with declining population. Turning that decline around, must be the priority of the next mayor. I see that happening through a strong economy– new construction, tearing down abandoned buildings, and creating new jobs. Then improving our schools and access to child care, so new families see a place they want to raise their children. Then improving our quality of life with new access to the great outdoors, parks and rec, and places for families to play. We can accomplish those three things together, and we will create a community that will be the envy of Alaska. The borough and city of Fairbanks have a complicated relationship and are often at odds on certain topics (downtown plan and joint economic development agreements). How do you think the borough better facilitate partnerships with North Pole and Fairbanks? One of the first thing I’ll do is to begin to rebuild those bridges with North Pole and Fairbanks.
